content.description: SDS on West side of boulder. Make a big first move and head right on edges and precarious feet. Topout at the corner. - Taken from Travis K's Google Map description.Â 7/22/2020 Update: based on comments from others, I believe the original House Cat route is indeed intended to follow strictly the middle. Do not use the upper shelf in the beginning. If you do, the problem is closer to a V3-V4 problem. I have updated the picture to reflect your choices.
content.location: West facing side of the House Cat Boulder. Neighboring to giant slabby rock spine.

content.description: Start low on South side of boulder. Climb left through a sea of thin edges. Topout as for House Cat. - Taken from Travis K's Google Map description1. You can try and start lower than what i've pictured here as the start, but i've had so many pieces rip off while attempting to add on more moves to the main body of the route that I just didn't care anymore. 2. Some of your feet choices may break off, this side of the boulder is quite flakey but nothing dangerous. The main pieces for feet and hands will be solid and safe.3. Try to stay on the lower sea of crimps. There will be crimps near the very top of the problem once you get closer to the crux. I don't believe you're supposed to use them, and it takes away from the difficulty of the crux.
content.location: South facing side of House Cat boulder. Neighboring to giant slabby rock spine.

content.description:
Originally found on the Google Maps resource shared by Travis K. The problems listed there will point you exactly where to go. Housecat is on that list: goo.gl/maps/KMZkwcWd1yeeV1ej7

 A solid boulder with 2 well-established problems, and possibly a third short one. The top of these problems are classic South Mountain flaky pieces so the risk of pulling something off is possible. All three problems are 95% solid though.
